definitions.definition: the part or side of something that faces forward; the side of something that you look at first
definitions.sensetop: on the frontup the frontdown the front

examples.text: The front of the building was covered with ivy.
The front of the car was badly damaged.
The book has a picture of Rome on the front.
The jacket zips up the front.
a green sleeveless top which buttons down the front
Check the position of the pockets on the jacket front.
I usually end up with gravy down my shirt front.
She stared into the large mirror, running her hands down the front of her dress.
The dress is embroidered at the neck and down the front.
They run an annual competition for tidy shop and house fronts.
The drawer fronts are made of solid mahogany.

definitions.definition: the position that is directly ahead of somebody/something

examples.text: I turned round to face the front.
Keep your eyes to the front and walk straight ahead.
There's a garden at the front of the house.

definitions.definition: the part of something that is furthest forward
definitions.sensetop: at the frontat the front of somethingin the frontin the front of somethingto the front (of something)

examples.text: The singer came to the front of the stage.
The teacher made me move my seat to the front of the classroom.
She always sits at the front.
Our carriage was at the front of the train.
I prefer to travel in the front *(= next to the driver in a car)*.
Write your name in the front of the book *(= the first few pages)*.
The dining room is to the front of the house.

definitions.definition: the part of somebody’s body that faces forwards

examples.text: She was lying on her front.
I spilled coffee down my front.

definitions.definition: the side of a large building, especially a church, that faces west, north, etc.
definitions.sensetop: the west, north, south, east, etc. front

examples.text: the west front of the cathedral

definitions.definition: the road or area of land along the edge of the sea, a lake or a river

examples.text: Couples walked hand in hand along the front.

definitions.definition: an area where fighting takes place during a war

examples.text: More British troops have been sent to the front.
to serve at the front
fighting a war on two fronts
Reports from the battle fronts became briefer and vaguer.
Even young teenagers were sent to the front.
Thousands were killed on the eastern front.

definitions.definition: a particular area of activity

examples.text: Things are looking unsettled on the economic front.
Things should get a little easier on the work front soon.
Progress has been made **on all fronts**.

definitions.definition: behaviour that is not what it appears to be, done in order to hide somebody's true feelings or opinions

examples.text: It's not always easy to **put on a** brave **front** for the family.
Rudeness is just a front for her shyness.
She put on a brave front, but I knew how miserable she was.
Without that false front, I wouldn't be able to face the world.

definitions.definition: a person or an organization that is used to hide an illegal or secret activity

examples.text: The travel company is just a front for drug trafficking.

definitions.definition: used in the names of some political organizations

examples.text: the Animal Liberation Front

definitions.definition: the line where a mass of cold air meets a mass of warm air

examples.text: a **cold/warm front**

definitions.definition: if you put on a piece of clothing back to front, you make a mistake and put the back where the front should be

examples.text: I think you've got that sweater on back to front.

definitions.definition: in somebody’s presence; in front of somebody

examples.text: He had seen his life's work destroyed before his very eyes.
Before our very eyes, the bird snatched the fish from the plate and flew off.

definitions.definition: with immediate payment of cash

examples.text: to pay for something cash up front

definitions.definition: to show people that all members of a group have the same opinion about things

examples.text: The prime minister stressed the need to present a united front.

definitions.definition: in or into the most important position

examples.text: The issue has moved front and center in his presidential campaign.

definitions.definition: in a position that is further forward than somebody/something but not very far away

examples.text: Their house is the one with the big garden in front.

definitions.definition: in first place in a race or competition

examples.text: The blue team is currently in front with a lead of six points.

definitions.definition: in a position that is further forward than somebody/something but not very far away

examples.text: The car in front of me stopped suddenly and I had to brake.
The bus stops right in front of our house.
He was standing in front of me in the line.
She is now entitled to put ‘Professor’ in front of her name.

definitions.definition: in a position facing somebody/something

examples.text: to perform in front of a big crowd/audience
She spends all day **sitting in front of** *(= working at)* her computer.
She's a natural **in front of the camera** *(= being filmed/photographed)*.

definitions.definition: if you do something in front of somebody, you do it when they are there

examples.text: Please don't talk about it in front of the children.

definitions.definition: still to come; not yet passed

examples.text: Don't give up. You still have your whole life in front of you.

definitions.definition: to take an active part in what you are telling or persuading others to do
in the part of a theatre, restaurant, etc. where the public sits

examples.text: There's only a small audience out front tonight.
He cooked while she sat out front and waited tables.

definitions.definition: in the area near to the entrance to a building

examples.text: I’ll wait for you out (the) front.

definitions.definition: as payment in advance

examples.text: We'll pay you half up front and the other half when you've finished the job.

definitions.definition: in a forward position

examples.text: to play up front

wordOrigin: Middle English (denoting the forehead): from Old French front (noun), fronter (verb), from Latin frons, front- ‘forehead, front’.
